thread.title: Dutch create world's largest man-made wave
thread.title_full: Dutch create world's largest man-made wave

title: Dutch create world's largest man-made wave
text:
Dutch build more dunes against rising seas November 20, 2009 
On the beach at Monster, bulldozers painstakingly turn sand dredged from the bottom of the North Sea bed into dunes in an ambitious effort to safeguard the Netherlands from flooding. World learns from Dutch to keep head above water March 21, 2011 
Dubai's Palm Island, New Orleans' upgraded dykes and Australia's water recycling plants all have one thing in common: they benefited from Dutch know-how gained in the country's age-old quest for dry feet. Dutch government encourages self-driving car tests June 16, 2014 
The Dutch government says it wants to encourage large-scale tests of self-driving cars in the Netherlands by next year, and supports a plan to allow tests of self-driving trucks by 2019. Dutch unveil big plan to fight rising tides September 16, 2014 
The Netherlands on Tuesday unveiled a multi-billion-euro, multi-decade plan to counter the biggest environmental threat to the low-lying European nation: surging seawater caused by global climate change. Researcher predicts increased flooding in the Netherlands January 15, 2015 
In the future, due to climate change and corresponding extremely high water levels, rivers in the Netherlands will be more likely to break their banks. This was the conclusion reached by the Dutch researcher Suleyman Naqshband ... Floods as war weapons: Humans caused a third of floods in past 500 years in southwest Netherlands June 9, 2015 
A new study shows that, from 1500 until 2000, about a third of floods in southwestern Netherlands were deliberately caused by humans during wartimes. Some of these inundations resulted in significant changes to the landscape, ... Recommended for you Dutch create world's largest man-made wave October 5, 2015 
In a country where most people live below sea level, studying the oceans is a matter of survival. Now Dutch scientists have created the world's biggest man-made wave in a bid to prepare for the worst. Liquid cooling moves onto the chip for denser electronics October 5, 2015 
Using microfluidic passages cut directly into the backsides of production field-programmable gate array (FPGA) devices, Georgia Institute of Technology researchers are putting liquid cooling right where it's needed the most ... Facebook, Eutelsat in African Internet satellite hook-up October 5, 2015 
European satellite operator Eutelsat Communications and social media giant Facebook said Monday they are working jointly to deliver satellite broadband Internet to connectivity-hungry sub-Saharan Africa. Price of solar energy in the United States has fallen to 5c/kWh on average September 30, 2015 
Solar energy pricing is at an all-time low, according to a new report released by Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (Berkeley Lab). Driven by lower installed costs, improved project performance, and a race to build projects ... Two years of tests confound two decades of assumptions on lithium-ion battery design October 2, 2015 
A Stanford undergraduate has contributed to a discovery that confounds the conventional wisdom in lithium-ion battery design, pointing the way toward storage devices with more power, greater capacity, and faster charge and ... Incident of drunk man kicking humanoid robot raises legal questions October 2, 2015 
A few weeks ago, a drunk man in Japan was arrested for kicking a humanoid robot that was stationed as a greeter at a SoftBank, Corp., store, which develops the robots. According to the police report, the man said he was angry ...
